Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Program Officially Starts
Notes: Any list of the most egregious IT project failures of the past ten years has to include the US Air Force’s Expeditionary Combat Support System. ECSS was supposed to be a single integrated enterprise resource planning (ERP) system built using commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) software, and aimed at modernizing the service's global supply chain. The original estimated life-cycle  cost of ECSS was put at some $3.0 billion, with about $1.2 billion allocated to development and $1.8 billion for operations and maintenance. The plan was to have a fully deployed system by 2012. After some early re-planning exercises to reduce program risk, the project had a "new" start in May 2005. (A note of caution—no one really has an authoritative set of financials on ECSS. That was made clear in the US Senate investigation report, which expressed frustration and outrage that the Air Force couldn’t tell it what was spent on what, when it was spent, nor even what ECSS had planned to spend over time. Various reports have conflicting data on estimated and spent costs.)
url: GAO-08-866 Air Force Asset Visibility http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d08866.pdf; GAO-13-311 Defense Major Automated Information Systems www.gao.gov/products/GAO-13-311

Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Major Contract Awarded
Notes: Computer Sciences Corp. is awarded one of the largest contracts, for $628 million to provide technical and business transformation services. In early 2006, USAF also paid Oracle $90 million to license the software that the system was to be build with. The intended capabilities of ECSS are still a bit of a mystery. At this point in time, the the Air Force said that ECSS was going to “replace more than 400 legacy systems” to over “over 700 legacy systems [PDF]”.
url: Expeditionary Combat Support System: Root Cause Analysis (See Figure 3) www.acq.osd.mil/parca/docs/2011-ida-rca-ecss-p-4732.pdf

Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Finances Get Murky
Notes:
The 2008 GAO report says that the total life cycle cost is still $3 billion, but also notes that the Air Force acknowledges that the program is going to overrun that amount, because functionality that was supposed to go into the DEAMS project was now to be merged into ECSS. The number of legacy systems that are going to replaced starts to drop, with a number of about 250 being bandied about (although over 400 legacy systems continues to appear in USAF literature)..

(DEAMS, the Defense Enterprise Accounting and Management System, is a project which, beginning in 2003, aimed to replace nine Air Force legacy accounting systems at an estimated life cycle cost of $420 million by October 2009. It is now scheduled to be completed in April 2017 at projected life cycle cost of $2.2 billion.)
url: Expeditionary Combat Support System: Root Cause Analysis (See Figure 3) www.acq.osd.mil/parca/docs/2011-ida-rca-ecss-p-4732.pdf

Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Reality Check
Notes: By 2010, the cost of ECSS had jumped to $3.4 billion for development while operations and maintenance stayed at about $1.8 billion, and full deployment wasn’t now going to happen until 2016 at the earliest. The first piloted release of ECSS had problems with data quality, data conversion, interoperability and integration, usability, information assurance and requirements testability. As a result, program management decided to restructure ECSS to improve data quality, update the Oracle software to be used, increase the number of releases from three to four, as well as restructure how the program was being managed.

Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Program Reassessed
Notes: In late 2011, the US Air Force and the Office of the Secretary of Defense were both conducting reviews of the program, saying that the “development and implementation of ECSS had lagged." The project's spending was now $876 million, with another $110 million worth of outstanding contract obligations. Now the Air Force says ECSS is saying that ECSS is replacing 240 legacy systems.

Program: US Air Force's Expeditionary Combat Support System
Headline: Program Cancelled
Notes: In his testimony to the Senate Armed Services Committee's Subcommittee on Readiness and Management Support in April 2012, the Air Force's comptroller, Jamie Morin said, “We're now approaching seven years since funds were first expended on this system. The total cost is now over US $1 billion. I'm personally appalled at the limited capabilities that program has produced relative to that amount of investment.” Yet even the increased cost and schedule estimates were optimistic: after spending over $1 billion, the Air Force admitted that it would cost another $1 billion to get just 25% of the system’s planned capability. With ECSS spinning out of control, it was officially cancelled in December 2012 at a cost of arond $1.1 billion. (Our final estimated timeline is necessarily rough; no one bothered to figure it out how long it would actually take once they saw how far behind the project already was. Eight more years would seem like a reasonable estimate given that they would be effectively starting over from scratch.) If the numbers given in a 2011 Institute of Defense Analysis (IDA) report (pdf) of ECSS is correct, some $5 billion plus in lost opportunity costs have been incurred as of 2015, and it is likely another $7 billion or so at least will be incurred if a replacement is not in place by 2017. Just how mismanaged was the project? A 2014 Senate investigative report into the debacle noted, “To date, the Air Force still cannot provide the exact number of legacy systems ECSS would have replaced.” At the present time, an ECSS replacement is being planned, but how much it will cost, how legacy systems will be replaced, and when it is expected to be operational the Air Force isn’t saying, although it is promising it will cost less than ECSS. Why did ECSS fail? There are three different publicly available reports (one from IDA (pdf), one from the Air Force (pdf) and one from the Senate (pdf) providing a host of reasons to choose from, but if one were sum them up, management incompetence coupled with excessive hubris and a desire not to hear negative news would probably capture 95% of it. While promising to learn the lessons from previous similar large-scale IT failures (its own as well as others in the Department of Defense), the Air Force management not only studiously ignored them by seemed to willfully defy them. Additionally, as the IDA report noted, bring up bad news required “courage.” Finally, who was held accountable for ECSS’s demise? No one as it turned out. The Air Force’s senior leadership made it crystal clear that firing or demoting anyone for blowing $1 billion on an absolutely useless IT system was “not necessary.” A candid statement if there ever was one that goes a long way towards explaining why no one in ECSS ever brought up bad news.
url: GAO-13-311 Defense Major Automated Information Systems www.gao.gov/products/GAO-13-311

Headline: Contract Starts
Notes: North Carolina awards the first contract to Computer Sciences Corp. for a new Medicaid claims processing and management system called NCTracks. It is the second try, after spending $30 million on an earlier attempt.

Headline: Project Rescoped and Schedule Sips
Notes: According to the state auditor, “in July 2010, CSC (the vendor) notified the Department that it would not be able to meet the established go-live date and requested an extension. After lengthy negotiations, the Department approved a contract amendment in July 2011 that granted an 18-22 month extension to build the system, increased the contract price from $265 million to $484 million, and extended the operational contract an additional two years to 2020.”

Headline: Increased Delays
Notes: System delayed to accommodate legislative and regulatory mandates

Headline: Premature Launch
Notes:
The system went live 1 July 2013, and experienced major problems. While it was being developed, North Carolina spent at least $36 million (net) to keep its legacybenefits  system going because of the delay.

In reality, the schedule should have been slipped another 6 months to a year, but there was ptretty much a political decision to move forward with it. Medicaid certification was expected for summer 2014, but that didn't happen until March 2015 because of extensive bugs in system. NCTracks really couldn’t be considered “fixed” until March 2015 of this year when it received Federal certification.

Headline: Project Officially Starts
Notes: The Disability Insurance Automation project was aimed to automate a number of manual work processes involved when filing for a disability insurance claim.

Headline: Project Rescoped
Notes: Procurement issues cause schedule slip but project cost reduced.

Headline: Project Reassessed & Reset
Notes: California Employment Development Department recognized that it had underestimated the complexity and effort required to create the system, so the project is rescoped. Deloitte Consulting will be paid $52 million to build system. Development now begins in earnest.

Headline: Project Scope Changed
Notes:
Project scope changes increase life cycle costs and schedule. Development costs climb another $8 million.

A state legislative report from May 2012, attributed the increases to “costs that often accrue over the lifespan of a project, including increased state staffing needs, enhanced system functionality or scope increases, and data center costs, among other things.”

Headline: System Launches Early
Notes:
The system launches "ahead" of schedule, but there are several months of working through frustrating "transition" issues.

It is clear that the total development cost would be more than $60 million if we included the state's incurred costs, but we don’t know how much since the details of the total amount spent on the project aren't broken out in any audit report.

Headline: Project Officially Starts
Notes:
Califonia's Employment Development Department originally planned two system developments. The Call Center Network Platform and Application Upgrade (CCNPAU) was meant to create a single networked infrastructure for EDD’s call centers which will interact with an intelligent call routing system. The Continued Claims Redesign (CCR), was intended to develop an interactive Internet website and telephone application that would allow customers to file unemployment insurance claims and to recertify on a biweekly basis by Internet or phone.

The Call Center project was targeted for completion in 2006.

Headline: Project Officially Starts
Notes:
Califonia's Employment Development Department originally planned two system developments. The Call Center Network Platform and Application Upgrade (CCNPAU) was meant to create a single networked infrastructure for EDD’s call centers which will interact with an intelligent call routing system. The Continued Claims Redesign (CCR), was intended to develop an interactive Internet website and telephone application that would allow customers to file unemployment insurance claims and to recertify on a biweekly basis by Internet or phone.

The Claims Redesign effort had a larger budget and timeline.

Headline: Projects Merge
Notes:
Three years later, just a few months ahead of CCNPAU's original completion date, both projects were merged into one due to multiple interdependencies. From what we've pieced together, nothing much had happened during that time. One document that says that a project planning phase started in July 2005 and ran into 2006. What happened in 2004 seems to be a mystery.

The merged projects would maintain separate schedules. CCNPAU completion was pushed back four years (longer than the initial scheduled development time).

Headline: Projects Merge
Notes: Three years later, just a few months ahead of CCNPAU's original completion date, both projects were merged into one. Both projects still maintained separate schedules. CCR also received an increased estimate and delayed launch date.

Headline: Project Costs Increase
Notes: A year later, due to changes in the procurement approach, the cost of CCNPAU had risen yet again, but the timeline was optimistically reduced.

Headline: Project Costs Increase
Notes: A year later, due to changes in the procurement approach, the cost of CCNPAU had risen yet again, but the timeline was optimistically reduced. Meanwhile, CCR costs and delays continued to mount.

Headline: More Cost Increases and Delays
Notes: Another two years into the project, CCNPAU costs and delays were growing again.

Headline: More Cost Increases and Delays
Notes: Another two years into the project, CCNPAU costs and delays were growing again. But now CCR saw a schedule reduction! (The completion date was only moved up a single month, though).

Headline: Call Center Upgrade Launches
Notes: CCNPAU was rolled out in May 2011, missing it's 2009 deadline by four months (and the original deadline by over four years). It wasn't a smooth launch; complaints about call wait times were rampant.

Headline: Call Center Upgrade Launches
Notes: CCNPAU was rolled out in May 2011, missing it's 2009 deadline by four months (and the original deadline by over four years). It wasn't a smooth launch; complaints about call wait times were rampant. And CCR's launch was delayed by another year.

Headline: Claims Redesign System Launches
Notes: CCR was rolled out over Labor Day weekend, also four months off of its final deadline (but over five years late according to the original schedule). By the way, the launch was a total disaster. Since launch, the state has spent approximately $4 million on upgrading and fixing CCR.

Headline: IBM Wins Contract
Notes:
IBM is awarded a $98 million Shared Services Initiative (SSI) contract to provide Queensland-wide human resources and financial solutions.

As a small portion of this contract, $6.19 million is budgeted for creating a new payroll system at Queensland Health. Considering the state has already tried (and failed) to build such a system before, they should be aware that it's an impossibly low estimate.

Headline: Nothing Delivered Yet
Notes:
Six months in, an auditor would later note that nothing of consequence has yet been delivered.

There's a slight increase in project cost and schedule.

Headline: Focus Now on Payroll
Notes:
The payroll system is not close to being completed. IBM now says that the cost to provide Queensland-wide human resources and financial solution is now $181 million. That's too much, so the larger initiative is scrapped. 

Instead, the new focus will be on getting the Queensland health payroll system to work. IBM has already spent a total of $31 million of its $98 million contract, including monies spent on payroll system.

Headline: Test Issues Force Delays
Notes:
Same estimated payroll project cost, but an increase in schedule.The goal is now just to get the Queensland Health Payroll system done. What should have happened was a total reassessment of the project, and a new project cost and schedule caculated just to do the payroll system. But this wasn’t done.

The payroll system development was supposed to be a quick, low cost solution that spiraled totally out of control.

Headline: Test Issues Force Delays
Notes:
Same estimated project cost, but an increase in schedule.

There was lots of work during this period, but little progress. The schedule slips were generally due to not being able to get a stable system that could pass the system tests.

Headline: Test Issues Force Delays
Notes:
Project cost is increased, and scheduled lengthened. 

The major problem was the complexity of the labor contracts and labor categories involved. There are reportedly 24,000 different ways the staff can be paid, based on 13 different award structures and 13 labor agreements. The schedule slips kept happening because of the issues involved in trying to test the system.

Headline: Test Issues Force Delays
Notes: Same estimated project cost, but an increase in schedule.

Headline: Test Issues Force Delays
Notes: Same estimated project cost, but another increase in schedule.

Headline: System Launches Prematurely
Notes:
The system (still not fully tested) goes live, and with disastrous effects: over 18,000 staff affected, with 1,800 not paid or underpaid. The total staff numbered 78,000. Many got the correct pay one pay period, but not the next. The total number of affected staff who had at least one pay period screwed up is unknown. In total, there are $14.5 million in salaries glitches.

IBM cost for payroll system now is $25 million (it has been paid $22 million); government says total cost of payroll system including its own expenditures amounts to $102 million.

Headline: Time to Double Down
Notes: Govt decides to spend another $209 million to try to fix system

Headline: System Relaunches
Notes: Govt claims payroll system is stabilized

Headline: Not Over Yet
Notes:
At least $440 million is estiamted to have been spent on developing the system. Up to another $100 million may be needed to fix the system completely, while $837 million will be needed to operate it for next 5 years; $91 million in salary overpayments are still outstanding. The estimate of total life cycle cost is at least $1.25 billion to as high as $1.35 billion. As of 31 May 2012, 200,000 processes were still being performed manually on 92,000 forms every two-week pay period by over 1000 Queensland Health payroll employees;  in order to make it work, the payroll system contains thousands of modifications and customizations, with some 130 manual workarounds being employed.

Some $5 million was spent by the inquiry that was set up to try to make sense of what happened.

Headline: Project Start
Notes:
FiReControl was to replacing 46 local control rooms with a network of nine purpose-built regional control centers using a national computer system to handle calls, mobilise equipment and manage incidents. Initial rollout was due in October 2007, with a final scheduled for October 2009. 

The project costs include both IT and facility construction costs since neother could operate without the other.

Headline: Reality Creeps In
Notes: By February 2006, the people involved began to realize that the project was severely under-estimated in both size and complexity--especially the information technology that would be required. The FiReControl project was reassessed, and a new estimate of £340 million was published. EADS is hired as the prime contractor in March 2007 to develop the IT system required; the contract could be worth up to £200 million over eight years.The initial roll-out is now set for October 2009, with a final completion date set for end of 2011.

Headline: RealityBites Hard
Notes: The project was just poorly managed with little oversight or insight into the project by the government. In April 2008, EADS admits that the technology needed to develop a critical element of the system was no longer working. Fully operational system now set for early 2012.

Headline: Project Problems Abound
Notes: Same project cost, but an increase to the schedule. A major review is discovering ineffective project management, poor project planning, and poor working relationships between suppliers and the government are rampant across the effort.

Headline: Project Terminated
Notes:
Project terminated in December 2010 after spending £250 million and not impending much of value; another £219 million in already committed costs, so a total spend of £469 million; another £180 million could be spent, the May 2015 date was a best guess, since the program was still estimated to be at least 5 years from completion.

The final “estimated” cost to complete in December 2010 was  £635 million with a rollout beginning sometime in 2012 and going through who knows when, and even that was iffy. They had already built the regional control centers and agreed long term leases which they are stuck paying for.
